title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
The Supreme Court curbed the FTC's longtime practice of seeking to recover ill-gotten gains in court from companies and individuals who cheat or mislead consumers.

---

Intel CEO Gelsinger said a global chip-supply shortage could stretch two more years, as the U.S. semiconductor giant posted weaker quarterly earnings.

---

Initial jobless claims fell to 547,000 last week, a new pandemic low that adds to evidence of a strengthening labor market.

---

Major airlines this week reiterated confidence that the travel market, at least for leisure, is rebounding from deep pandemic losses.

---

Credit Suisse asked investors for up to $2 billion in fresh capital after losses from Archegos swelled more than previously disclosed.

---

The ECB will keep its aggressive monetary stimulus in place and lag behind the Fed in phasing it out, Lagarde said.

---

U.S. stocks fell, with the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq all retreating 0.9%.

---

SEC chief Gensler hired veteran defense attorney and former prosecutor Alex Oh to run the agency's enforcement division.

---

AT&T added more cellphone users, fiber-optic internet customers and HBO viewers in the first quarter.

---

Blackstone Group swung to a record quarterly profit, reporting net income of $1.75 billion.
